qas.question: When was the Collegiate School of Saybrook Colony founded?
When was the Collegiate School renamed to Yale College?
Why was the school named Yale College?

answers.text: recognition of a gift from Elihu Yale

qas.question: When did Yale first incorporate humanities and sciences?
When did Yale issue the first Ph.D in the United States?
When was the Collegiate School of Saybrook Colony closed?
When wasn't the Collegiate School renamed to Yale College?

plausible_answers.text: recognition of a gift from Elihu Yale

qas.question: Why wasn't the school named Yale College?
When did Yale last incorporate humanities and sciences?
When did Yale issue the last Ph.D in the United States?

context: Yale University is an American private Ivy League research university in New Haven, Connecticut. Founded in <a0_0><b5_0>1701<b5_0/><a0_0/> in Saybrook Colony as the Collegiate School, the University is the third-oldest institution of higher education in the United States. The school was renamed Yale College in <a1_0><b6_0>1718<b6_0/><a1_0/> in <a2_0><b7_0>recognition of a gift from Elihu Yale<b7_0/><a2_0/>, who was governor of the British East India Company. Established to train Congregationalist ministers in theology and sacred languages, <a3_0><b8_0>by 1777<b8_0/><a3_0/> the school's curriculum began to incorporate humanities and sciences. In the 19th century the school incorporated graduate and professional instruction, awarding the first Ph.D. in the United States in <a4_0><b9_0>1861<b9_0/><a4_0/> and organizing as a university in 1887.
